div.head: Capel Lofft (1751–1824)
div.p: According to Ditchfield, Capel Lofft, the radical writer and editor was first exposed at Peterhouse, Cambridge, to “a spirit of theological heterodoxy which influenced him for the rest of his life.” As a country gentleman of independent means, he was able to cultivate “a serious interest in English literature, history, classics, foreign languages, botany, and astronomy,” representing “the best of the amateur tradition in learning.” Promoting radical politics, Lofft was an associate of William Hazlitt, Crabb Robinson, and other Whigs of the Regency.
Although brought up in the Church of England, Lofft became a Dissenter, embracing Unitarian doctrine, which is reflected in the poem that Ruskin knew, Eudosia; or, a Poem on the Universe (1781).
